admreg: Middle East and North Africa,Middle East and North Africa
trustfund: TF039842-YEMEN REPUBLIC - HEALTH SECTOR REFORM,TF035980-EGYPT - HEALTH SECTOR REFORM

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            unsatisfactory, although sustainability is likely, and
            institutional development impacts are modest. Lessons are
            divided in two sections, a) those relevant to program
            development prior to project effectiveness, and, b) those
            applicable during program implementation. Prior to project
            effectiveness, lessons address the need to minimize the time
            period between appraisal, and effectiveness, noting the
            project should have begun with a review of activities, and
            components focused on sectoral priorities; the need to
            ensure appropriate counterpart funding, to facilitate
            effectiveness, through the availability of resources; while
            given the weak implementation capacity of the public sector,
            consideration should be given to alternative management
            strategies, based on adequate assessment of institutional
            capacity; and the development and application of effective
            evaluation strategies. During implementation, Government
            commitment should be ensured, through demonstrated
            improvements to the health sector. Moreover, stronger
            attention should be paid to the achievement of the
            project's development objectives. This was evidenced in
            the overly ambitious development objectives, without an
            established institutional analysis to support objectives,
            nor to gauge program implementation, experienced through the
            weak performance indicators, or lack thereof. However, it is
            fair to say that flexibility allowed support for the health
            sector reforms, and the Drug Fund. Finally the lack of
            training hindered the appropriate use of medical equipment
            and technology, which will be further jeopardized if
            operating budgets are not ensured.
